title: 107_hr2805
content: The Act is titled the "Post-Abortion Depression Research and Care Act". The Congress finds that approximately 1,186,000 unplanned pregnancies in the US end in elective abortion each year. Abortion can have severe and long-term effects on women's mental and emotional well-being, leading to symptoms such as post-abortion depression, guilt, eating disorders, and suicidal urges. Abortion can lead to various mental health issues such as substance abuse, intrusive thoughts, decision-making difficulties, and lack of social support, resulting in emotional distress over time. Women who have had an abortion are more likely to report substance abuse and experience negative emotional effects compared to those who have suffered a natural pregnancy loss or carried to term. Post-abortion depression can be exacerbated by lack of social support and societal understanding. Social pressure to have an abortion can lead to immediate regret and long-term mental distress. Prompt diagnosis and personalized care, including therapy and medication, can help treat post-abortion depression. The emotional aftermath of abortion lacks research sponsored by the National Institutes of Health. Research on post-abortion depression and psychosis is being expanded and intensified by the National Institute of Mental Health. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the National Institute of Mental Health, is expanding research on post-abortion depression and psychosis. Coordination with other national research institutes is required, and programs for post-abortion conditions will be conducted or supported. The Director of the Institute will conduct or support research on post-abortion conditions, including basic research, epidemiological studies, diagnostic techniques development, clinical research for new treatments, and information/education programs. Additionally, a longitudinal study will be conducted. The Director of the Institute will conduct a national longitudinal study to determine the incidence and prevalence of post-abortion conditions, symptoms, severity, and duration. Reports on the findings will be submitted to Congress periodically. $3,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006 for this purpose. Establishment of a program of grants for delivery of services regarding post-abortion depression and psychosis. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants for projects to establish systems for delivering services to individuals with post-abortion conditions and their families. Grants can be given to public or nonprofit entities, including hospitals, community organizations, and health centers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to public or nonprofit entities with experience in providing services for post-abortion conditions. Projects may include outpatient and inpatient care management services for individuals and their families. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants to public or nonprofit entities to improve health care services for individuals with post-abortion conditions and their families. The program will integrate with other grant programs and grants will not exceed $100,000 per fiscal year. SEC. 202. CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS. Under section 201, a grant requires the applicant to agree to specific conditions: 1) Limiting administrative expenses to 5%, 2) Using the grant to supplement, not replace, other funds for post-abortion treatment, 3) Following Secretary-imposed limitations on charges for services, and 4) Not using the grant for services already covered under section 201(a). The applicant must post notices at service sites informing individuals of federal policies regarding charges for services provided under section 201(a). The Secretary may provide technical assistance to help entities comply with the requirements of this title to be eligible for grants under section 201. $300,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2002 to 2006 for carrying out this title.
